results.title: Producing a plan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of planning, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Most critical production decisions are made before anything has been produced. Care must be taken to avoid vital errors in such things as shop floor layout when plans are first made.

results.title: Investment planning
results.creator_credit: David Hargreaves, Paul Ellis and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
Aims to clarify some of the problems of forecasting for managers of small and medium-sized businesses, thereby achieving control through forecasts. An investment policy is a plan for the future, and as such it needs to be both simple and effective.

results.title: Control by budgeting
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Management Techniques”.
One of a series of films about some of the problems of forecasting, and of trying to achieve control through forecasts, particularly in the case of small and medium-sized firms. Shows how budgets can be prepared to avoid running a business at a loss.

results.title: Performance appraisal
results.creator_credit: Don Sykes, Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Management by objectives and performance appraisal”.
An industrial education film which uses animation to review all the steps for successful and beneficial performance appraisal, including the gathering of facts, discussion of concrete, measurable objectives, and actual performance, and development of future work goals an plans. With leader’s guide.

results.title: Developing objectives
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow, Kaiser Aluminium and Chemical Corporation and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Management by objectives and performance appraisal”.
An industrial training film which uses animation to show employees methods of writing and developing work objectives which are understandable, measurable, challenging, achievable, and with a target dagte for completion.

results.title: What is MBO?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Management by objectives and performance appraisal”.
Management by Objective starts with an objective agreed to by supervisors and subordinates, with time limits. Concentrates on result, measurable and achievable The key is two way communication after manager identifies basic purposes of the unit and evaluation after the objective has been reached. Consists of cartoon drawings but is not animated.

results.title: Man: a course of study
results.brief_description: The course of study is designed for upper primary or lower secondary level but can be introduced effectively at any level. It deals with the basic questions: What is human about human beings? How did they get that way? How can they be made more so?

group_works.title: The Baboon troop
group_works.creator_credit: Quentin Brown and Educational Development Centre

results.title: The Baboon troop
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown and Educational Development Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man: a course of study”.
Explores the social structure of members of a baboon troop. Shows the role of the male as the protector and central figure, the females’ bonds of affection for their offspring, and the establishment of the dominance hierarchy among juveniles.

results.title: Man on the rim series
results.creator_credit: Quantum Films, Anthony Buckley and Robert Raymond
results.brief_description: Over two years in the making, this series about the Pacific Oceean, the people who live around it and across its vast expanse, has breathtaking photography and fascinating narration which illustrates that what we are learning about this area comes from the descendants of the original inhabitants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Quantum Films, Anthony Buckley and Robert Raymond
